title: A New Treatment for Leukaemia on the NHS
summary: Oscar Murphy, a 28-year-old man, was the first patient to get a new treatment called CAR-T therapy on the NHS for his leukaemia, a type of blood cancer. He said it was fantastic and very sci-fi. This treatment uses his own immune cells, which are changed in a lab to fight the cancer. It happened at Manchester Royal Infirmary hospital. The NHS is now funding this treatment to help about 50 patients each year. Oscar had leukaemia that came back after other treatments, but this new therapy gave him hope. Doctors say it is safer and works better than old treatments, helping patients live longer. It is a big step in fighting this fast-acting cancer.

background_read: Leukaemia is a serious illness where the blood has too many bad cells. The NHS is a healthcare system in the UK that helps people for free. New treatments like CAR-T therapy use science to make the body's own cells fight cancer, which is exciting and can save lives.
Article_Structure: WHO: Oscar Murphy, a 28-year-old patient with leukaemia
WHAT: He received CAR-T therapy, a new treatment that changes immune cells to target cancer
WHERE: At Manchester Royal Infirmary hospital in the UK
WHY: To treat his aggressive leukaemia that returned after other treatments, offering a safer and more effective option

perspectives.description: Oscar finds the treatment fantastic and sci-fi, giving him hope for a longer life.
Dr. Eleni Tholouli says CAR-T therapy is safer and more effective, revolutionizing cancer care.
